They claimed that it was really busy, and that they "didn't forget the meal, it just took forever to cook," which was very obviously not the case. It was very clear that they had forgotten the order. They then tried to give us the two drinks we had gotten for free, and we said that we wanted the late meal free, not two random drinks that we had ordered. Finally I had to ask to speak to the employees manager, and he took the meal off of the menu for us. 

I know this place isn't a fine dining restaurant, and had they been busy, and had I not had better experiences in the past, it probably wouldn't have seemed like as big of a deal. But tonight was ridiculous, and I don't have any plans to go back to S & E Cafe. Eat at your own risk, as it's a different experience each time.
author: Amanda B.

description: Came here after a night of drinking on a Saturday. It was pretty empty when we walked in.. only a few tables were taken so we got seated right away.. it was weird cause I was used to tons of older Chinese people there and the workers also being older but that night it was full of young people and young workers.. guessing the owners sons and stuff? ANYWAYS dude was really nice and really helpful and it was just amazing service. food was good too.. so much better than ABC but just a little pricier but you get what you pay for right..
author: Tiff C.

description:
Dear S&E cafe,

I am sorry about last night. Or was it this morning? It was one of those nights of partying and drinking that really screwed me up. Shortly after I ordered my food, which tasted great and came quickly, I fell asleep next to the other half of my club sandwich for about half an hour. When I woke up, I threw up in your sink, which is probably clogged by now. I avoided the toilet because of my bad knee and because I didn't want to touch the toilet or the ground. I am really sorry. Your restaurant has great food and great service. From what I remember, the club sandwich was great, and did a good job of keeping me full for that half hour. I will come again for sure! I wont throw up in your sink anymore!

-Danny
author: Danny Y.

description: After several tries with the new management, I found this place more affordable than before.  Service can be a hit or miss depending if they are busy.  The last visit, I had great service!  I like how they continuously try to improve their food because when I first had their baked pork chop over rice, I was not impress; the sauce was too americanized for me.  Then it was way too salty, and lastly it was good but could be better.  Moreover, I would like to try their seafood puff soup, as it seemed to be on the menu again! Oh, they also offer specials on occasions such as mother's day, v-day, etc.  P.S. their lemon ice tea is delicious. full of sugar but damnnnnnn so good!
author: Ann L.

description:
Pros: Open until 2 AM
Really good cheung fun(rice roll with the peanut and satay sauce)
Good prices and good sizes.

Cons:Parking
Service
I don't recommend anything to do with beef/steak (except the fried rice). They just mess it up somehow the two times we ordered it.
author: Wilson T.

description:
This place actually isn't bad if you want a HK style type food.  I've been here a couple and the food is decent, nothing special but decent.   A word of advice, order the HK style cuisine and you'll be ok.   I have tried their other stuff like fry noodle and it was uh ... a bad MISS.   Don't suggest you try anything on the wall too like their "specials".  

Was here for Valentine day dinner ... I know, I know.... it was late and we were tired from work and happen to be in the Sunset.  $34 bucks for one order of the Valentine day special:

1 Salad (from Costco, saw the box in the kitchen)
1 So call Giant lobster tail (Tiny as hell .... also from costco)
1 Pumpkin soup with lobster meat (hardly any lobster in there)
1 Strip Steak (WTF ... they cut the steak strip in half ... one tiny piece...suspect from Costco also)
1 Tiny slice of so call fish fillet

Other then that, ok place,
author: Guess G.

description:
monday night munchies!

relatively cheap, decent food.  i shared the chicken steak [gai pah] with my friend, and it came with soup of the day [veggies in a chicken broth, unremarkable] and hot milk tea.  the "tomato" sauce over the chicken was certainly HK tasting [ketchup-y] and it was over a large helping of rice.  they took the time to bake the cheese on top of the dish, which i thought was nice.  

i would come back if i expect to hang out until 2 am on a weekday night because of their decent prices and o.k. food.  knowing some cantonese helps to make things go smoother too, but not neccessary.
author: Tina A.

description: We had a late supper here after the Bay to Breakers run in the morning. We arrived at the restaurant at around 9:00 pm and the restaurant was pretty much full. Luckily we were able to get a table without having to wait. I ordered my favorite baked pork chop rice and my wife had their Special of the day which was grilled salmon and sole fillet with prawns. The baked pork chop rice was quite good and so was my wife's meal. The fish was moist and juicy, but could use a bit more seasoning. The prawns on the hand were cooked to perfection and were crisp and flavorful. I also had the coffee/tea combo (free refills). It was strong and good. Service was pleasant. I would come back again to try some of their other dishes.
author: David Y.

description:
This place opens up late and its fancy-ish. I came here and ordered a baked pork chop with rice. It came out with two big pieces of meet and pre cut. To some of you cutting the meet is part of the eating process but I find that these precut pork chops were moist and juicy. It doesnt come in the silver tin plates in most of the other restaurants. 

Their service is nice and welcoming. I like this place a lot solely because it opens up late. I tends to be a bit more pricy than other asian restaurants around the area but i feel that this restaurant has the quality that backs up how much they are charging. 

For sure when I come here next time that I will be ordering their cherng fun.
author: Benjamin C.

description: Stopped by yesterday to pick up my usual- ketchup sauce baked pork chop over rice. It comes with a small side of soup and a crostini. Yummm!! If you check in on Yelp, you also get a free iced lemon tea or soda. Great service and awesome prices!
author: S D.

description: Guy friend took me here for dinner pre-3 day fast. It was like our last supper. He told me that they had remodeled the entire place. The place looked clean and well kept. BF says that it is HK style food. We were seated right away. i ordered the grilled pork chip which came with either rice/spaghetti and a healthy sized portion of steamed veggies. The meal came with a choice of tea or milk tea as well as dinner rolls and a soup as a starter. All for less than $15. Steal. Food came out fast and piping hot. Everything from soup to milk tea to the rolls was fantastic. i will definitely come back for more.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I had dinner here for the first time and it was mediocre.

Nothing in the restaurant was interesting expect maybe the flat screen t.v.s. But I couldn't even see them. Patrons were seated west and east as the t.v.'s were positioned on the north and south of the restaurant. 

I ordered a won ton noodle and my brother ordered a steak rice. My brother asked for tea, but the waitress said they didn't have any and MADE him order a coffee. What a jip! I ordered a red bean ice and there was more ice than drink. 

I would say this is a more modern looking ABC restaurant if anything, and I think ABC has better tasting food.
author: Amy C.

description:
My parents and I come here about once a week for their delicious, quality food. They serve every meal with H.K. milk tea, dinner rolls, soup/salad, and dessert. I always get the H.K. style baked chicken spaghetti, which is amazingly delicious every time. It is super cheesy and the tomato sauce is delicious. The escargot is  really good and served with an abundance of garlic. Some dishes are better than others with the baked dishes being the greater. I've had salmon over rice with mushroom cream sauce, which came out to be kind of bland. 

 They have one of the best H.K. milk tea I've ever had and it is STRONG so be sure to not drink too much at night. Speaking of, they open past midnight so if you have the munchies, this is the place to go for good quality food. 

Their prices are fairly inexpensive and their portions are large.The staff is friendly and attentive. It is also very clean with a comfortable ambiance. They updated their menu and remodeled the restaurant not too long ago, so its nice that they strive for improvement. This place serves great H.K. style/western food, I'm really surprised they don't have lines by now.
author: Denise W.

description:
My favorite cafe thus far. I didn't believe it when people said their milk tea was strong, but g'damn I found out the next day my friends were rolling around in bed all night too. Speaking of the milk tea though, it's smooth and not too sweet. Did I mention it was super strong?

I love that they serve dinner rolls, soup, a drink and dessert with your meal. Gonna try to come back and try out everything so long my wallet permits! Definitely a happy customer.
author: C. C.

description:
I came here tonight after a movie because my friend was feeling sick and wanted me to pick him up some congee to go.  This is the only place in the area (along the L muni route) that serves congee and is open after 10pm on a Tuesday, so I didn't have many options.

But wow does this place suck.  It took them about 35 minutes to make chicken congee!  And during that time, no one came by to check up on me until maybe 2 minutes before the food was ready.  Seriously, all you have to do is scoop it out of a premade bowl and add some scallions and sliced chicken.  That doesn't take 35 minutes!  To add insult to injury, the congee was really bland and there were only a few pieces of chicken in it.  It was almost like eating plain congee.  I also noticed that everything on the menu was more expensive than other similar HK style cafes in the neighborhood.  Too bad T-28 is closed on Tuesdays, or I would have gone there instead.  The bottom line is to stay away from this place, you can get better food for cheaper.
author: Tyler C.

description:
Date/Time:  Sunday - 2:30am
Occasion:  Late night dinner after birthday celebration drinking
Party of:  Four
Location:  Right on 19th Ave so easy to find.  Clean, plain interior for a HK style cafe.  
Ordered:  Ox tongue and mushroom with spaghetti and tomato sauce + French toast & condensed milk.
Total incl gratuity: ~$15pp

This place definitely hit the spot for late night eats.  I was actually really hungry as I hadn't quite filled up from dinner so I was ready to grub.  I hear their late night menu is nothing compared to their ridiculously extensive day menu.  I'm really curious to know what that looks like!  Our server did mention that most things from their day menu were available late night by request.  Nice!

Nonetheless, I went with my ox tongue and mushroom spaghetti.  It was really good and the portion was fairly large.  I thought the tomato sauce was perfect for my entree; it was very thick and hearty.  I had a nibble of the french toast with condensed milk and felt a little indifferent about it.  It was served with french fries, which is so bad to eat at 2am, yet oh so good.  I think I've found my new place to go after the late nights.
author: Jess C.

description: I went here with my family for dinner. We ordered dinner combinations: steak and fish, which both also came with drinks. Although the food was okay, the service was okay. Although some of the waiters and waitresses had great attitudes, some were completely rude. When my friend got her milk tea, she actually got iced coffee, so she told the waiter that she got iced coffee instead of milk tea. He didn't believe us, so he DRANK the iced coffee. He brought us iced milk tea after, but it was completely rude and offensive. Unless further action is taken, I won't come here again.
author: Wayne L.

description:
Disappointing for four reasons.  

1). It was my sons graduation day and he wanted prime rib.  We called S &E and 
     we asked do you have prime rib.  They said "yes".  We asked how much.  They
     said around $21.00.  We went there and ordered prime rib and they said "we don't
     have prime rib tonight."  I was mad and disappointed. I even told them someone 
     here said that you have it. 
2)  When it was time for dessert, the waitress said we have red bean soup.  We asked
      is this included  in our meal.  She said "I will give this to you."  Keep in mind this  
      Hong Kong style restaurant which I think dessert is included.  
3)  We got our bill, it showed the cost of the meal, tax and total.  I noticed the 
     gratuity section showed the gratuity was based on the meal.  So I gave them my 
     credit card.  When I got the bill back to sign, the gratuity was higher because it  
     was based on the total bill. 
4)  The soup was very bland.  The oxtail and the beef tongue were not cooked long 
     enough so they were tough.  My sons steak was good but for the price $18.50, it 
     was thin.  

We came here once (about two years ago) and thought it was much better then. We would not come here again.  Sorry
author: Susan L.

description:
My first time here and it was nice. The restaurant seemed very modern and i loved the interior design of the place. The only thing that sucks is parking. 
I ordered the Pork chop over cream sauce with a side of hotlinks inside. It was Delish! My Girlfriend ordered the Ham and somethingy majig, and it was alright. The food was not over cooked and they didnt come inside a metal plate like most HK style restaurant. 
The food was nice and flavorful and it did not disappoint.  

The bathroom was clean and had a very interesting square toilet that you must see. The HDTV in the restaurant was great for viewing when you run out of things to talk about. 

This place is a go if you are craving hong kong style dishes.
author: Sovanda R.

description:
I give them an extra star for being open late during a weeknight besides Seniore's Pizza & having a nice clean setting. ANyhow, after a long play at sfsu, my pals and I were starving and we wanted something mom and pop yet filling sans breaking the bank. I had the tofu with white gravy over lightly sauted white rice and scrambled egg. The meal included a warm dinner roll with butter, corn & egg drop soup, HK tea and a dessert of jello. With tip, I paid $15. I did go a bit further than my expectations, but I had a to go box for the next day's lunch. 
In addition the food comes fast and well presented. 

THis place doesn't do spicy chinese food nor the type of Chinese food that Mandarin Speaker enjoy.(  Despite not speaking Mandarin, Its in my genes to like spicy food.) I had to ask for sriracha.
author: R C.

description:
As I have come here practically once a week for the past few months, S&E Cafe has grown on me.  

The extremely nice waitresses and owners have consistently reserved table space for us, been accommodating to some of our broken Chinese, and have sometimes provided complimentary milk tea, soups, and desserts.

A word of warning though: The milk tea is extremely potent.  Two cups of the tea can keep me awake three hours longer than usual.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Ate dinner here the other night with a friend.

I drive on 19th all the time, and I somehow seem to miss this place anyway.  

I ordered a steak for dinner.  I wanted medium but it was still a little too bloody for me.

The waitress... I had something to say about her, but now I can't remember.  I guess that's what I get for not writing my reviews right away.....
author: Tina L.

description:
Late night options tend to be restricted to A) Denny's, B) Seniore's, C) In-and-Out/Fast food.  Hubby was craving Chinese food so we decided to go to S & E for the first time.  When you walk in, this place is packed, filled with young and old alike, craving a late night snack.  There are nice flat screens on the wall, of course showcasing E News in Chinese, displaying the Bieb.  This reminds me of San Jose's VIP without the bar.  

I ordered the baked, creamy porkchop with noodles.  In hindsight, I should've ordered that with rice.  The porkchop was so-so and the noodles were plain with no taste.  the best part of the meal was the dinner roll and clam chowder!  If I just ate that I would be satisfied.  My friend ordered dried egg noodles with chicken (tasted exactly like chow mein).  Hubby ordered bbq pork, won ton, noodle soup.  Looked amazing, tasted so-so.  Bottom line: Chill spot with variety of Chinese dishes/snacks for late-night munchies =)
author: Steph W.

description:
This place is the spot now ever since its remodel and kitchen change. This HK style cafe has a nice ambiance, and is definately the most comfortable and clean, compared to the D&A, ABC, etc..... Staff is very chinesie, but very attentive and gets me whatever i ask right away. The food seems more creative then from over a year ago. I really like their baked items, chicken wings, rib-eye with mushroom sauce, and chicken wings. 

This is my top choice for Cafe within the area. Plus now they're open till 4am on fri/sat night. A definate plus for after a long night of whatever you've been doing.
author: Steve T.

description: Good food here. Very large portions. I couldnt even finish my fish and tomato sauce with rice. I had to take home which I didnt mind bc I got to eat it for breakfast the next day. I will most likely come again :)
author: Claudia M.

description:
My family and I have always been a fan of this place. Unfortunately since the change in management, S&E Cafe isn't open for lunch anymore as it once was. Nonetheless, it's open super late and is a great (and delicious) option for those of you craving HK cuisine!

Definitely have to say the place has definitely upgraded since it first opened some years ago. The restaurant itself is much cleaner than some of the other HK style restaurants that you might find in the city. The staff is very friendly and the menu features a variety of dishes that will surely satisfy most if not all of your cravings. I would definitely recommend any of the baked dishes! You can choose from a range of sauces including a cream-based white sauce, tomato sauce, or black pepper sauce. I would definitely recommend the Baked Pork Chop Over Rice, the Portuguese Style Chicken Over Rice, or the Hong Kong Style Chicken Steak Over Rice! The meat(s) are savory and, once you add in the sauce and the rice, you've got a delicious meal to enjoy. These are a staple in the HK cuisine and the portions here are more than enough - each dish comes with a soup and bread (both of which are delicious and a nice starter) and milk tea or coffee. The milk tea is quite good and has a nice hint of sweetness when you ask for the condensed milk. If baked dishes aren't your thing, there's also sandwiches, noodle soups, and other rice and noodle dishes to choose from.

If you've got a Yelp account, check in and they'll give you a free soda or iced lemon tea (one of my favorite drinks at HK restaurants)! 

Word of caution: parking sometimes sucks in the area so be prepared to walk a block or two if necessary.
author: Cheston W.

description: so this new lady that just started working took my order shes nice and really friendly. I ordered a mushroom chicken steak over rice and they gave me mushroom pork steak instead and I called the lady back and told her this was not what i ordered and she's like no this is what you asked for and I'm like no its not and i even asked my friends did i order the chicken steak and they were like yea and she's like well I can't do anything and I'm like wow and the thing is i don't eat pork so why would i order that. so i gave it to my friend instead.
author: Anna Y.

description: I would always pass by this place because I would always go to sushi raw and this place is across the street from it. The location is a little off from the busy street but it's close enough. Thought I would give it a try since I love Chinese food at cafés. I ordered the stir fried flat noodle with beef and my bf ordered a Macau baked porkchop over rice. They also gave us their soup of the day, which was Russian borscht. I never tried it but I'm glad I did because I am so in love with it. I even drank all of my bf's and the guy gave me a complimentary one since it didn't come with my meal but it came with my bf's. The food was really good at a decent price and had huge portions. The waiter was so friendly and energetic that it kind of rubs off on you. I will definitely return to try their other items and they are opened till 2am, which is great for those late night hungers. Their lemon iced tea is also very good. It's just lemon iced tea but at smiling house, which is a block away, their lemon iced tea tasted like a Lipton tea bag and a lemon. It lacked flavor. In comparison to smiling house, come to s&e because the waiters are actually kind and not rude, and the food is actually good and worth paying for. They also accept card!
author: Brenda K.

description:
They've definitely improved in their quality of food since a year ago.  I think this is due to the fact that they have a new kitchen staff that is very creative with their menu.  I like their Hong Kong style milk tea, chicken wings, escargots, and curry fish balls.  Try their angus rib-eye steak with the mushrooms sauce...tastes great!!  Or try their beef spaghetti with pesto sauce (not on menu)...this is what I usually get.  Beware...their servings are huge!!

The place is super clean for a Chinese restaurant...much more comfortable then ABC.  They are also open till 2am every night and closed on Tuesdays.  They just started to do late-late night on Friday and Saturdays with a limited menu but still that great taste and huge portions until 4am.
author: Patrick C.

description:
I came here with my parents and boyfriend for a quick dinner in the city.  It was on the tasty side of "meh."  

The oven baked entrees seem like a good value--$9 for a drink, soup, a dinner roll, and a large plate of rice or noodles, topped with a choice of meat and sauce--although given the location, you could probably find similar food for cheaper.  I tried my parents' Portugese style pork chop, and thought it was good, but not anything special.  It also had a disturbing taste of Velveeta... but maybe it was just the orange color that made me think of it.

My dinner was more delicious but sort of expensive: I ordered the braised beef and tendon with noodles soup.  The beef was very well seasoned, and the broth was delicious (light and flavorful, but not way too full of the beef sauce, like some places do it), but the portion was pretty small--maybe four small pieces of beef and four pieces of tendon, with about a fistful of noodles.  For $8, it was definitely not worth it.  

Overall, I had a pretty good experience here, but with all the options for Chinese food on 19th street, I'm not sure I'd come back.
author: Megan S.

description: The biggest perk about this place is that they are open late. I am a big fan of this because I am always hungry late at night. Another perk is this place is affordable. The food isn't the best, but they are good. And the last positive is they have a lot on their menu. It meets everyone's need.
author: Sonlay V.

description: Prices haven't gone done or anything, but I've actually enjoyed my experiences here the last two visits. The  food has been good but most of all, it just looks cleaner and feels cleaner than the other HK style cafes. They also have a pretty good kids menu, and the kids entree includes  soup, dinner roll, drink and dessert (just like an adult entree). My son loves that he gets everything I get, because most times at other restaurants, he has to share with mom and dad.
author: Dom L.

description:
this place has gone downhill...............................
Went there often for dinner and liked going there because it felt cleaner than ABC, but the more often we went the nastier the food seemed and the smaller the portion. The last visit has made me decide to put them on my ban list. Went there with a group of friends, and the service was horrible. The waitress forgot everything and was in a permanent bad mood. And the food, eh....... my baked salmon cream's sauce was watery (probably caused by the fish being frozen) There was not one item that our group ordered that was yummy.
author: Erica B.

description:
Don't know why this place only got 3 stars.  But the food is good, service was good, and the ambiance is good.

We ordered the Ma's Special Minced w/ Egg, and the Baked Pork Chop over Rice w/ Portugese Sauce.  Both were excellent.

They are open late!  Convenient!
author: Vance K.

description: The food are really good. I always order the seafood rice with Portuguese sauce. Even my friend like it. However, they should hire more people, it took 5 mins for them to notice I was standing by the door and wait to be seat. The girl tends to mess up the order there, lucky it was not in our table. Overall the food are delicious, I will come back again. Just to keep in mind they close on Tue.
author: Bing M.

description: Average food but slow service.  It took them over 15 mins to serve one item. Yes, the kitchen served one item from 12:50pm to 1:05pm!!!  The kitchen staff was napping???   So if you are hungry, definitely go somewhere else.
author: Patrick C.

description:
I love this place! I've been eating here for years. My all time favorite dish is the baked chicken steak with rice and cream sauce. It's under $10 and comes with soup, bread, hot milk tea, and the entree. It is absolutely delicious and I find myself craving it!! Also, their portions are huge!! 

This restaurant is nothing fancy, but is a good place to go to if you're just looking for a quick place to eat. Affordable, delicious, & convenient!
author: Kristina W.

description:
Beware of what you order! The pasta dishes are a no go! Stick with baked rice dishes! Those are green light all day! Baked Pork Chop with Rice, Baked sea food with rice... anything baked is really good here!

This place is definitely a step up from ABC and D&A. Just look at the decor. Very clean, fully remodeled! 

Service is very attentive, food comes out fast.. unlike ABC where its cold, dirty, and food sometimes takes awhile! To bad this place doesn't open late or else i would pick this over ABC any day!
author: Brian P.

description: Okay this place isn't much to look from on the outside, but there is a very friendly mom & pop feel inside. The menu ranges from Americana to the Orient. My favorite dish is the Portuguese spaghetti. Trust me on this, give it a try and you will want it again.
author: Benjamin G.
Susie N.

description:
Everyone orders. T - Spam/Egg Macaroni in Soup [SOFT FOODS FRIENDLY!], D - Stuffed French Toast w/ Peanut Butter, K - Wonton Soup.

D is stuffing her face with French toast. T asks for a tiny bite to try. D reluctantly cuts a piece and quickly finishes the rest before anyone else in the group can interrupt. Probably not as amazing as this (http://www.foodnetwork.com/food/recipes/recipe/0,1977,FOOD_9936_28780,00.html), but STILL!

Another late night option, perfect for right after Dragon Lounge, since their last call is so early, and they tend to kick people out by 1:40. Extensive HK-style cafe menu - food overall is probably just OK to bad, but that French toast was yummy yummy. If only they had condensed milk...

Even though they were closing at 2, they didn't kick us out or rush us. 3 stars.
author: Tinna H.

description:
If you really want to get the true S & E experience, healthy won't be in your vocabulary :) I give this place a HEALTHY RATING of 2.0/5.0.

I don't claim to be an expert of HK-style food, but my Cantonese friends who came with me said the food was good, so that has to count for something, right?

As many of the Yelp reviews suggest, we got the fried chicken wings. They served us the wet wings by accident, but they were so good that I really couldn't complain. They were crispy, flavorful, and fresh! This alone made my trip to S & E Cafe worth it. If I'm going to splurge, this is definitely worth it.

The other dishes that we got were just so so, including the Almond Chicken, Black Bean Sauce Noodles, and Dried Sautéed String Beans. The sauce used for the chicken and noodles tasted very similar (even though I don't think it was supposed to). In fact, when we brought our leftovers home, we ended up just mixing the two and heating them up together. The string beans were okay, but a bit salty.

I will say that their portions are huge. You will definitely leave this place with leftovers unless you are a skilled eater :)

The only other comment I have is about the wait. Instead of using a host/hostess to take down names, they hang a whiteboard next to the front door and have people sign up themselves. As there are a lot of people who want to eat here, it gets confusing whose name goes where and who was here first. As a result, I had to hover over the board in the crowded entrance to make sure no one was stepping in front of me.
author: Sean C.

description:
Whenever I'm in and around the Sunset area on the latenight tip, this is the spot I hit. It's pretty much your typical HK style cafe, similar to ABC (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ezLa_XcMRNBAgDEU6eeeAA) or Broadway Bistro (http://www.yelp.com/biz/V8OScvscIu3y8TPhKyRhAg?fsid=MfNMwhggv4VovbcpT3AJ2g). However, it's not as trashy as the first, nor as stuffy as the second.

Anyhow, the food itself is decent, but nowhere near the best in town. Any of your basic HK fusion style dishes can be found here, such as Portuguese chicken/pork chop, curry beef stew, baked seafood covered in cheese, chicken/pork chop with corn, etc. all over rice or spaghetti. At 1:17 am, it's plenty good to fill me up, although it's not exactly a scintillating feast by any means.

The service can be a bit shoddy at times, with the waitresses sometimes acting like they don't want to be there. The good thing is that they have never kick us out no matter how long we sit and chill.

S&E is actually a cool hangout spot for the local teenagers and college aged kids, and it looks like many of Sunset's finest like to patronize at the wee hours of the morning. My crew and I have been known to spit a few lines or two at the customers here.  =P

There is also nightclub right above, but I have never been inside. I don't know if they are connected or not, but it seems a bit shady to me, and always gated up. Maybe one day, I'll have to check it out.
author: Eric W.

description:
whoa, they remodeled so it doesn't look like a squatted McDonald's anymore.

The menu's still the same and the food is as inexpensive and tasty as ever but now they've got a wood theme in the store, nothing deluxe but it's definitely an improvement plus all the employees now wear matching black polo shirts.

It's nice and will probably bring in more business but if you're already a regular of the place you'll be glad that they didn't take the budget out of the grocery or cooks budget.
author: Keith A.

description:
If ABC Cafe asked Denny's on a date in ABC's 1990 Toyota Tercel and ABC had its way with Denny's S&E is the bastard child that would come out.  

This is how the child would turn out.  

1.  Food, definately from the ABC side.  They also serve escargo.  Not sure where they got the snails, but they do give you an ittybitty fork to pick those little suckers out.  I think they also serve frogs as well.  

The snails btw, weren't gross, but I couldn't get myself to eat more than 2 without almost vomiting.  Just the thought.  

The standard items are simple and VERY simple.  Spaghetti w/pork chop and the lot.  

2.  Cleanliness:  Denny's for sure.  The water glasses I think were clean and I didn't have to hot water boil my silverware before using it.  

3.  Prices:  Somewhere in the middle, not the $4 slop from ABC

4.  Service:  Probably more on the Denny's side (ABC servers communicate with grunts and scowls

5.  Hours of operation:  I probably would not go out to this place in the daytime, but at 1:30am its pizza across 19th or this joint.  

Overall I like the location, food and service, however at my old age I frequently am in bed by 10:30.
author: patrick o.

description:
The food here is VERY similar to ABC (in the Sunset and Chinatown).  It's Chinese as well as HK style American food.  The food here never disappoints.  I normally just get chinese food here but their baked pork chop has also been very good.  I like the macaroni soup with chicken and ham strips...brings back memories.  I've also had their lychee/long on young coconut drink.  While it's expensive for just a drink, it's quite tasty.  My sister LOVES their dinner roll.  If you order a hk style meal, it comes with the dinner roll but if you order a chinese dish, you get nothing.  The dinner roll is $1.00.

Service is eh...not as bad as ABC since it looks like it's family run.  Never too busy.   But food...GOOD.
author: Winnie L.

description:
Nothing too special here just some half way dinner like mom would make if she wasent happy  bland not very flavorful. This place was also quite expensive and dose not open until pretty late in the day.
I wouldn't go out of my way to go here but if u have a late night craving maybe. Another yelper put it a good way by saying they are trying too hard for an Asian-American fusion.
author: Matteo C.

description:
This place is conveniently close to my house and has late hours.  The food is pretty consistent, but the services stinks! I'm used to receiving horrible service at Chinese restaurants, but this one really takes the cake.  They never respond to you when you are asking about your order or if you request more water.  Just be prepared to raise your hand a lot when you come here.

For food, I do enjoy their Baked Rice dishes.  Their Baked Pork Chop over Fried Rice is prety good, the piece of meat is a good size.  I will admit also that they have a pretty good Portugese Sauce.  My mom enjoys it with the Baked Fish over rice. 

Overall, their portion sizes are reasonable for the price, but as I mentioned, service is way below average.
author: Cass J.

description: Despite the tacky purple awning, this place is solid. The Portuguese sauce kind of tastes like candy though.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
Finally a good tasting HK style cafe that is actually clean and modern!
I like the bathroom signs. The food is very good here - if you are familiar with HK style cooking.
author: Henry C.

description:
The new S&E Cafe that is around now is nothing compared to the old one. With the old one they had a "happy hour" of sorts with tea sets of smaller portioned food that was perfect. Now there is a place that tries too hard to stay with the times trying to cater to both the Asian crowd and the American crowd. The food itself for the price is uninspiring to say the least. The place is clean but I would say you can go to any other place in the sunset to get something better. The only thing that this place has is that it's open late at night.

Back to the food and it being bland. The portions seem to get smaller and smaller every time I come here, and their soups are just plain tasteless. The drinks seem like their big but they fill most of em with tons of ice just to make it look cool. The Singapore style noodles have no bite and they seem to even screw up the fried noodles also. If your desperate for a late night place to go and all your other options are gone I would still rather go across the street and get some pizza at Seniore's.
author: Jason Y.

description:
I ordered the baked chicken over spaghetti with white mushroom sauce.. yummy!!!

I actually stared at it for a while- thinking that wow! it's definitely much more presentable than cafe bakery and abc.. OH and t-28 ... the great thing about it is that they open LATE..

I would definitely recommend coming here at night.. with a bunch of your friends.. or if you get lonely and want to come here alone.. you can ask for kenny :]
author: Monica C.

description:
the location is horrible. right on 19th avenue (highway 1)
tons of cars. also it was a hot breezy day.
i wanted to sit in the back with my dad because i didn't want to sit near the door because outside is really dusty and thats where tons of people walk in.
so i said i want to sit in the back cause there was like 4 tables open..
the waitress said no.. its reserved.. im like wtf?  so i sat where she sat us. and i observed the next party of people and they asked how many were there and the waitress brought them to the back.
FOOD was alright but the service was slow.
author: Kenneth G.

description:
I want to say I am a big fan of this place, but their menu seems simpler than before, with fewer choices.  The service is very nice and friendly, which is a bit unusual for this genre of Hong-Kong-Style Chinese cafes.    Open 'til 2am, so this place is usually on my short-list.

For the uninitiated, think of this as the Cantonese equivalent of Dennys, complete with fried porkchops, but over rice.  Many HK-style equivalents of American cuisine, as well as the staple entries for late-night Chinese eateries - Beef Dry-fried Chow Fun, Singapore Rice Noodle or Chow Fun, Won Ton, practically ANYTHING over steamed rice, etc..

That said, I STILL prefer S&E over T-28.  What schlock over there!
author: Harry W.

description: overpriced HK cafe food.. I wouldn't even eat here if I was drunk.
author: Susy C.

description: I thought they had decent food.  I ordered the baked pork chops with tomato sauce and it was good.  the meal comes with a warm bun, soup, and a hot drink.  All for $7.95.  What a steal.  The waitresses were great.  They were courteous and asked us several times whether we wanted refils on the milk tea.  I would back agin.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
oh how i miss their Hong Kong style baked pork chops over rice :) SOOO YUMMY! I used to live in san francisco, until this past year, he finally moved us out of that hell hole! when i lived there, that restaurant was one of my favorite hong kong style cafe's in the sunset. Especially the bake pork chop dish, that's the only plate I get every time I'm there. One time I changed up my order and got some curry dish. OMG that plate was way too spicy! Im not a big fan of that.. even tho, my family's from Hunan China, the Spicy capital. always get the pork chop plate over rice, i don't think i ever tried it with noodles, but i don't think it's as good. the texture is a pretty big factor in eating and the taste is of course, rite there next to it. the rice helps the pork chop and tomato/egg sauce hold together, so that everything is just all in one bite, SO delicious! i miss the place :) they should open one up down in san mateo!

oh and they have killer sweet red bean soup dessert. i love cause it's sweet, and the fiance likes it a lot too. he always says.. if they're not serving that, he doesn't want dessert. :T
author: Annie Y.

description:
The food is good and the menu selection is broad, considering that it's open until 2 a.m. in the morning.   There aren't alot of places with good food at those hours unless you like eating at Denny's, Top Caf, the POS hawaiian cafe across the street that used to be Zim's , or...*shudders*   Berkeley's infamous Sun Hong Kong (now defunct, good riddance). 

So far, things have been reasonably good.   I was pleased that the curry chicken over rice had solid pieces of lean chicken in it (some of the other late-nite places have very fatty chicken).   The three meat noodles was tasty, although the quality of the pork pieces wasn't that good.    The yang chow fried rice was good...generous amounts of shrimp thrown in for good measure.   

Service isn't outstanding.    Expect to be aggressive in asking for tea or extra napkins.   Nobody actually came around to refill tea the whole time that my friend and I were eating there.   I found it rude, but laughable, almost to the second that we finished our meal (at around 1:30 a.m.), the waitress almost instantaneously teleported over to our table to present us the bill, as if they couldn't get us out fast enough.   

It's not that cheap ($7-$9/plate) but I'd rather pay a little more to avoid getting garbage on the table.    Besides, the location is convenient and they do take credit cards.
author: Jason C.

description: This place is great although I must admit I liked the old S&E more. I come here quite often and the service is nice. The waitresses are very friendly and can customize orders if you ask for it. The food is definitely a HK style but there is a bit of an "elegant" flare in the presentation of the food. It's the small things like the silverware they provide or the bit of garnish they have on the side. The food is more pricey than your typical HK place but I find the quality better here. I get the "baked chicken over rice" here and it's much tastier and probably cleaner than other places. The place can get pretty crowded though especially on the weekends. I think this is typical for all HK cafes in the city though.
author: Jonathan L.

description: This place is amazing!! My favorite thing to get here is ALWAYS baked spaghetti pork chop!! Everything else is also wonderful and for the price that it is, You cant get any better than that!! This is also a great place to come after you drink! They now open till 5am every friday and saturday!!
author: Malisa W.

description: A lot of stuff of mediocre to average quality but very inexpensive.
author: Mike L.

description:
This is just ok. I used to frequent here alot in early 2002. However the decor has changed, and so has the food. In some places, it's improved, like some of the dishes. However, the drink menu shrank, and the dinner combos aren't exactly all that appetizing. But if you gotta have some western inspired chinese food, this is pretty good. Locals come here, only because 100% Healthy Dessert is full, or they just kinda stumbled upon this place. 

Not exactly car friendly, parking is crazy to find. Sometimes you have to park 2 blocks away, but definitely better than say.... Clement St. in the Richmond. 

I will say that most of the appetizers, although strange, are tasty, and the remaining drinks they do have, are pretty good. It's always a treat to just come by and have some HK style milk tea. Good if you'd just want to talk, and not really eat.
author: Clinton L.

description: GREAT SERVICE!!! GOOOOOD FOOOD!!! ask for KENNY for reccommandations!!!!
author: Johnson C.

description:
Typical HK Style cafe with a bunch of random dishes thrown in the menu. Comparable to ABC, Cafe Bakery, D&A, and T28. 

This cafe is clean, very clean. A few wall mounted plasma TV's, accent painted walls, and bamboo decor. 

I ordered the S&E Special Porridge with chicken, fish, and scallops. The porridge was rather bland and lacked any flavor. I had to use soy sauce and pepper to enjoy it. 

Nothing spectacular, just cheap and fast.
author: Simon S.

description:
a-ok.  my singapore noodles met my expectations (better at lim3 tr33 though, mmm!)

clean shop, with 3-4 vizios on cbs news.  

square shaped toilet, now i've never seen this before.  no, i didnt take a deuce, but i imagine it'd be like sitting in my chair now and going...
author: Ethan L.

description: My fiance and I come here quite often when we feel like eating HK cafe food.  We usually come here late at night and get excellent service.  We love that each of their set meals comes with bread, soup, tea, and dessert.  Their baked and rice dish portions are large enough to split into halves of thirds which is a great money-saver.  I recommend their Ma's Special and baked rice/spaghetti dishes.
author: Sybil C.

description: typical little Chinese cafe. part of their menu is American, and the rest is Chinese. i ordered Udon noodles and shared an order of Chinese Broccoli with my cousin. the Udon was okay, but I can't complain since this isn't a Japanese place. it was satisfactory considering it was cold and late and we just wanted to get something hot and soupy. also, the Chinese Broccoli did not look like Chinese Broccoli, but tasted fine... so who knows, we assumed it wasn't even Chinese Broccoli. overall, okay place. useful for late night or wanting a simple tummy filler, but not necessarily good  food.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
i come here when i don't feel like driving to lucky chances for a guaranteed late-night eating spot.  i've been here twice, and the service and the food is spot-on.

the drinks are refreshing and tasty. the grilled turnip cake is just as good at night as it is during dimsum at other establishments, and the entrees are satisfying when you're in the mood for something hong kong-esque.

i've never tried the baked pork chop, but next time when i do, i'll have to see if it's as good as st. anna's in oakland.
author: Lucy W.

description: this place is like a high end version of abc but the food taste about the same... possible same cooks... we order my bake seafood over rice and baked fish over rice... taste ok, the dish looks like when it come out... notting really special or taste good... one thing plus they still serve you choice of coffee and bread butter... so that's koo i guess.. haven't been here since summer time...
author: JessePanda C.

description: the roommie and i went here to have a late night dinner and i don't think we'll be coming back. the restaurant looks nice and clean, unlike most chinese restaurants opened late. and the service was good. the owner(?) was asking us how the food was and how we were doing and he was being really nice. we ordered a portugese style spaghetti to split and the portion was decent, they even brought out a bunch of other food and dessert for the both of us. buuuuuuut... we didn't feel so good after we ate it. lets just leave it at that.
author: Anh P.

description: The food has really gone downhill .. it seem like ever since the place was redecorated , the food got worse . The curry beef chow fun ( my favorite dish ) no longer tastes as good as it used to . It's not as flavorful ): The chicken wings are good though .. I like how they're fun-sized haha ! The radish cake is okay .
author: Eileen L.

description: I like this place cause it's open pretty late and I have an affinity for oven baked entrees. All I ever order here is either the oven baked fish with white sauce or the oven baked beef with white sauce. Both are pretty good, as well as some of the other dishes my friends have ordered so I can say this place is well worth visiting. They also serve hot Coca Cola with lemon which is interesting. The only think I hate is the location (19th and Taraval) because of parking.
author: Rommel N.

description: food and service is okay, but parking around 19th is tough luck.
author: Valerie N.

description:
I don't really like this place. The food here is really bad and half-assed. The only reason why I frequently eat here is because it's open til really late and my friends like a sit down place to eat (which seniores across the street doesn't offer). 

Whenever I come here...i really don't see anything appealing that I would like to eat. On one of my latest visits here, I thought I was playing it safe by getting the grilled cheese. That was a mistake. Basically, they're version of the grilled cheese is to put two pieces of bread into the toaster and then putting cheese in between in hopes that the toast is hot enough to melt the cheese in the middle. Well, they were wrong. I could tell that they used two slices of american cheese because the cheese had not melted together! This was a disgrace to the All-American Grilled Cheese Sandwich...they neglected the grill part. 
My plate wasn't the only bad thing. My friend got the clam chowder and it took forever to come. When it finally did, it was the consistency of watery rice porridge and had gross canned clams in it. It was unappetizing.  They could have done better by just opening a can of Progresso.
And speaking of soups, my bf had a soup with his meal and it was this cheesy bacon thing. it wasn't even real cheese. Seriously, it tasted like they used the powdered cheese packet from the Kraft's mac n cheese box. Ughhh....just thinking about it right now makes me want to throw up.
All in all, the reason why i didn't just give one star is because they are open late...catering for night-time owls who eat dinner late sometimes. This to me is the only reason why this place is even popular.
author: Ivy L.

description:
this place is a rip off. 
i ordered some typical HK cafe food which are span & egg macaroni soup, turnip cake with XO sauce and seafood cream soup souffle, each 3 food item failed in Quality and Quantities.  
The macaroni soup charges $7 is way over priced and felt nothing special to justify its higher than usual cost. 
The Turnip cake with X.O. sauce costs $4 is more like "turnip cake croutons" small pieces on a small dish..
the seafood cream soup souffle is so watery, it tasted like cream flavor hot water.. 
i felt insulted with the price they charged me.  I really dont know how this restaurant can stay in business in a competitive HK cafe market in SF.  My GF said this restaurant used to be really good.. i guess not any more..   so patrons beware!!!
i wan to see this restaurant to be on an episode of Gordon Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmare..  but, can he fix a Chinese restaurant?????
author: Rukawa J.

description: The place does accommodate larger groups of people and is open late. The table is clean and service is great. They have an extensive list on their dessert menu. But most of them tasted really bland.  I probably would not go back again unless it's for social gatherings.
author: Elle W.

description: late night chinese food. cool.
author: Tony N.

description: It's alright here. Typical HK food place. I wouldn't suggest this place for actually eating, but more of a "sit-down-have-a-drink" place. However, I think that they changed (for the worse) over the years, because when they first opened, I remembered my dish being mMm Mmmm good! However, it could've also been the fact that I was young and anything new place that didn't taste like shit appealed to me.
author: Elaine H.

description: nasty food.  I had the curry, which no one can mess up, b/c they don't make it from scratch, it's just from those package powder kind that is pre-mixed and all you have to do is add water.  They even messed this up.  The instant noodle w/ spam is prob. easiest thing on earth to make, b/c god knows i can't cook but i can churn out a decent spam & egg instant noodle w/ a fried egg.  The noodle tastes nasty and I will not go back.  there are way too many of these restaurants in the city to deal w/ this one.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Grilled pork chop with black pepper sauce for the WIN!  I think I've eaten that at least ten times now.  Never really tried the other stuff, but I'm sure it's good or at least the pictures look good enough to eat.  

The only problem I have with this place is.  That it seems if you're not Chinese or HK people tend to stare at you like you're some kind of leper.  I just grab take out and eliminate that whole situation.
author: Nobou H.

description: Was going in there quite often, cause of the convenience, sorry to say not any longer! Owner only caters to his friends & customers of his dance club above the cafe. have you ever heard of refill your coffee only after you drank the last drop. I go to Denny's & take one sip & they come to refill the dam thing! Food ain't graet & way high, got the steak special, & you'll agree with the "where's the beef saying, a thin slice of  who know's what! looks like they took one steak & fileted into 3 steaks & call it  the special. waitresses trained to work their ass off, boss is always sitting there having tea or coffee & eagle eyeing the staff. He's got a head waiter or something that thinks he god's gift to waiters, everthing he says goes! Stay away, for that amount of $$$$ & leave hungry, better off going to taco bell/panda express! wish yelp had a negative star! ordered a cup of clam chow. to go & it took 45 mins & was no more than 8 oz. & costs more than $4.00. should've walked up to safeway & bought two cans! Ripped Off!
author: david c.

description:
to get it out of the way, i'm not chinese.

that said, i asked my chinese companions to order me something that the uninitiated would find at least somewhat appetizing. they did the best they could, getting me a pork-egg-corn-ricy thingy, with corn soup.

maybe i'm just not used to it. the mix of flavors was just kind of off, compared to most pork-[insert 3 ingredients here]-amalgams that i have. i might as well have dumped fish sauce and horseradish on it to complete the culinary roundabout set before me.

the corn soup was exactly as advertised: corn soup. it's like they got a can of corn niblets and put the can directly over the stove before putting it in the bowl. nothing special, no standout flavors, just corn. in starchy water. reminds me of old USF cafeteria food.

again, not being chinese put me face to face with food that doesn't exactly come with the territory. my friends did the best they could, i did the best i could, and it just didn't work.

on the flip side, i'd like any chinese person to try balut or dinuguan and see how they like it. some food just isn't for everyone.
author: Charles C.

description: I only give this place a 3 because it is better and cleaner than ABC Cafe. I've been here maybe two or three times, but they were not as bad as ABC, like I stated before. They have the typical cafe food such as, ramen noodles, etc. Prices are decent, people are decent, but I think I remember them taking forever to make my ramen noodle. Pissed me off.
author: Edgar G.

description: There is the old S & E Cafe and there is the new S & E Cafe and personally I LOVED the old one. I think it's been over a year since the menu has changed and over a couple months since they had their huge renovation. The place looks really nice now, but they cut down their menu a lot from what it was before. I guess I'm a bit bitter that they took out my old favorite dishes. Nowadays when I come in with my friends I take a long time debating about what I want to eat since I'm still not sure what's necessarily good there. But anyways, the food is decent, it's okay/cheap-priced, and it looks really nice. Oh yeah it's open really late which is good for late night diners. All in all pretty decent place but nothing too spectacular.
author: Julie L.

description: After a complete remodeling of the restaurant and possible owner change, S&E Cafe has become the perfect late-night snackhouse in town. Their variety of Chinese and "Gong Sik Sai Chan" literally "Chinese know make western dishes." is amazing. This ain't your daddy's ABC garbage, this is for some true cuisine seekers. They know how to make their food delicious and not even remotely disgusting. Fried rice, flat noodles, linguine pasta with pork chops, sandwiches, and a multitude of special sweet drinks make this place a unique dining experience. After the remodel, this place is clean, the staff is efficient, and I feel comfortable sitting in the restaurant. Before the remodel, the place felt like it didn't want you inside of it. Hopefully they can upkeep the way it looks now. -1 point for parking is insane sometimes and completely impossible on 19th
author: Chris L.

description: Very very friendly! I got a pina colada  and my boyfriend got a banana smoothie
author: Caitlin B.

description: The new remodel looks great!  I remember when it looked like crap but for some reason those were the better experience I had.  The other night I came here and the worst experience ever.  I ordered the Sweet and sour fish with rice.  They should just change it to sweet and sour sauce with a hint of rice and fish.  The sauce was so overwhelming.  This was the only time I ever had to dig through the sauce soaked rice to find some plain white rice to eat, how sad was that.  I ended up leaving the whole plate full of their red sauce mess.  I give this place a 3 star because its open late, as long as you dont get the sweet and sour fish you'll be safe.
author: David O.

description:
Last time I ate here was the old S&E. I tried a few months ago to eat at the new S&E at a busy time but left after waiting 15 min without having my existence acknowledged. I think the place is one of the best examples in SF of its type of cuisine (HK version of an American coffee shop--that's shop, not house, think Woolworth's lunch counter or Denny's/Lyons, not Starbucks), so this evening I decided to give it another try. Good thing I did.

Yes, the decor is much nicer, with the bamboo at the entrance, dark grained linoleum floors, wood-grained Formica tables and the framed food porn photos on the wall above each table. And the service was better than the previous reviewer said, with one of the waiters coming by now and then so see if I (or other diners) needed a refill on my lai cha (HK condensed milk tea) or needed ice water.

Tonight I got one of the two specials listed in Chinese at the door (the printed menu is completely translated, and the waitstaff will happily translate the door specials on request. Cheng tong hoisin saimin translates as soup with seafood and angle hair pasta. It was $13 and well worth it: a soup plate with broth containing salmon, prawns, some kind of white fish, with bits of asparagus and tomato. Yes, at this price the fish was probably farmed but it was all good and I finished it off.

The price included my choice of hot coffee or  tea, or for those in the know hot HK tea with sweetened condensed milk. True to its coffee shop origins, it also included a small cup of soup (chicken veggie with macaroni) and a dinner roll (nothing fancy, just like you'd get at a coffee shop). Jello or, again for those who know to ask, a cup of HK style barely sweetened red bean and tapioca soup for dessert.

If you're feeling nostalgic for mid-western food, this is the place. Just be aware that you're seeing it through an HK lens, and that the prawns come in-shell with tails (they did take the heads off, but that's not a given in these types of places). Keeping that in mind, it's a good buy.

(Just be warned, french toast at this kind of place generally comes without syrup.)
author: Charles B.

description:
This is a decent place in the Sunset for Hong Kong-style chow. In the past year or so they've updated both their menu and decor, both for the better, in my opinion. Yes, the prices are a higher than before, and they no longer do free substitutions with drinks (soda instead of coffee, for example), but this is quibbling. Before they offered a significantly wider range of choices (such as baked pasta), but they were very hit-and-miss. The accompanying vegetables in particular used to be served almost raw, without any seasoning whatsoever. Now they still offer both Chinese and Western dishes, but less of them, and everything on the plate is tastier.

My partner and I went there this past weekend. We ordered two of the dinner specials: pork chop with onion sauce over rice and the chicken with cream sauce and spaghetti. The entrees came with coffee or milk tea, a hot roll, soup of the day (ours was cream of spinach), and a red bean dessert. Both of us thought the soup was delicious, and it appeared they actually make it themselves rather than from a can. The entrees were both cooked well, the meat still tender and juicy. They came with a small amount of mixed veggies (zucchini, broccoli, and carrots) which were sauteed in garlic and butter -- quite good! I wish they had included twice as many veggies as they did. The pasta was also very good, with a hint of garlic and olive oil seasoning.

For about $10 a person, this was a satisfying meal and a good value. I'd stick to the mainstream dishes and you probably won't go wrong here.
author: Sasquatch M.

description: My favorite place to go, sometimes I try to go around 4PM since they open at 5, and they were happy to open earlier for my boyfriend and I. Menu has a variety of mostly H.K food, most of which are very delicious. Price is affordable, depending on which plate. Love everything about the restaurant!
author: N W.

description: So, I would say that S&E is a step up from ABC cafe on noriega.  If you want to escape the firm clutches of ABC without having to escape Sunset then you should try S&E.  I'll have to use ABC as a comparision tool on this review.  Same type of food, but with a much cleaner and renovated environment.  S&E certainly doesn't close as late as ABC though.   The food here is much prettier with more garnishings...a sprinkle of cheese here and a dash of parsely there.  They've gone with a cream of carrot soup instead of the vegetable soup you'de get from ABC.  I actually just ordered a cup watermelon juice (quite decently sized I would say) while my friend ordered the NY steak special posted on the front chalkboard, and a porkchop and fish meal.  I was surprized the NY steak meal came with two large shrimp wrapped in bacon.  And again, both dishes were quite nice to look at when compared to the meals from ABC.  Both my friends enjoyed their meals and said it was very tasty.  The guy on the table next to us had ordered some type of fried fish meal but told the waitress that it was too salty and she quickly told the chef and aksed him what he'd like in place of it. that was quite nice.  This review is getting way too long...so to sum it up,  S&E = Hong Kong Style cafe, cleaner than ABC, A SLIGHT variation from ABC, a LITTLE more expensive from ABC.
author: LittleBird 8.

description: all i can say is that this place is not my kind of food. service was nice but due to my preference, the food was not my favorite.
author: Rhonda H.

description: it's a good neighborhood cafe.  i wouldn't go out of my way to eat here unless i was in the area.  they are open late and the food is mediocre. the menu is extensive, but i recommend sticking to the basics like porridge or noodles.  i prefer this place over ABC on Noriega.
author: Big e.

description: Haha, well I guess I'm really no use with this review since I didn't order anything from here.  Two of my friends and I hung out really late one night and drove around sunset to see what was open for a quick bite.  The only place we discovered at the time:  S & E Cafe.  We didn't know when they closed, but we took our chances and parked on the street nearby.  We realized we got there 10 minutes before they closed.  We were the only guests and we were surprised that they actually let us order still even when they were pretty much all set to go.  Luckily for them, only one out of three people ordered something.  My friend ordered (the always safe dish)  baked tomato sauce over porkchop, rice and egg.  I took a few bites, and it was as good as I thought it'd be.  Personally, that's one of my favorite dishes at Western-style Chinese restaurants.  You really could never go wrong with that dish.  Anywho, good to know that the next time I come here, I should come wayyy before 2 AM lol.
author: Jasmine T.

description: The S&E has a new, improved, and expanded menu that is greatly appreciated.  All I need to make me happy is French toast at 2 A.M.  The place is really clean and the guy I assume is the owner is always chilling with some group in the back, which makes him look like a pimp.  Everytime I order here it is a gamble because the food is different everytime, but I cant bring myself to complain because I eat there so often.  I am the only non-Asian customer I have seen there, so it may only be a problem for me, but a few waitresses sometimes don't understand my order.  The news in the background always seems to spark good conversation.  I cant say many things bad about a place three blocks from my house, open until early morning, and pretty cheap.  It isn't outstanding but its good enough for me.
author: lup b.

description: after the remodel, i came to this place a lot to eat on late nights.  but one night while i was eating, i noticed a hole in one of the panels of the drop down ceiling and i saw a RAT jump out of there and onto the rail that is right under the ceiling!  needless to say, i haven't went back there since!
author: CONSUMER C.
